It's Spinal Cord Injury awareness day. Each year in the UK, 1,000 people sustain a new spinal cord injury. This is usually as a result of a traumatic event.

NICE has produced a guideline on the assessment and initial management of a spinal injury.

Go to: https://t.co/iHszLDKXbc https://t.co/Ojon42KjGx

@Deborah49004292 @BreesAnna @JuliaHB1 The JCVI (Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation) looks after vaccination, it has never been part of NICE’s remit. For more details on vaccination contact the Department of Health & Social Care.

@Deborah49004292 If you contact enquiry handling (nice@nice.org.uk) with your queries they will be able to provide you with further details. NICE doesn't have a role in vaccination so we are not looking at vaccine data.

@OisinsRide @Capacitylaw Hi - we have recommended the use of the Clinical Frailty Score in our COVID-19 rapid guideline on critical care in adults, where we say that in some people in whom it has been validated it can be used as part of an holistic assessment – as it was before COVID-19.

@jim_crawfurd @parthaskar @kamleshkhunti @drmarkporter @keithgrimes @RoyLilley Hi Jim, we have pointed out to those concerned that we didn't develop/endorse the COVID-19 decision support tool. Nor did we develop the Clinical Frailty Score, however we have recommended its use in our COVID-19 guideline on critical care in adults in whom it has been validated.

We welcome the recent clarification that the Clinical Frailty Score should not be used in certain groups, including those with learning disability and cerebral palsy (https://t.co/sFKPHU00p6), which we will reflect in an updated version of our guideline. (5/5)
The Frailty scoring system is not perfect, therefore we recommend that Clinicians should take any decisions about care in conjunction with patients and their carers where possible. (4/5)
The guideline says that on admission to hospital, all adults should be assessed for frailty, and that other comorbidities and underlying health conditions are also taken into account. (3/5)
Our new COVID-19 rapid guideline on critical care was developed to support critical care teams in their management of patients during this very difficult period of intense pressure. (2/5)
NICE is very aware of the concerns of some patient groups about access to critical care, and we understand how difficult this feels. (1/5)
